This bird vocalized spontaneously on the morning of October 14 2014 at about 05:10, with the waning half-moon high in the sky.  It approached whistled imitations but ceased vocalizing at about 05:16.

This is the first Peruvian record south of the Amazon.  Habitat at this site was tall forest on a nutrient-poor terrace, with an understory of Irapay palm (Lepidocaryum tenue).  The avifauna at the site has clear nutrient-poor affinities, with Crypturellus strigulosus, Notharchus ordii, Hemitriccus minimus, and Conopias parvus all present.
However, the forest here is not at all stunted.  Approximately  200 meters distant on the same terrace (and very near where the bird was heard initially on October 14), there is a tree ~135 cm diameter at breast height.  The ground is mostly clay, and well-drained.
